title: 500 Relevant Standards
summary: Don addresses the gap between public expectations and school delivery, citing Common Core State Standards and Ontario's Provincial Report Card as incomplete responses. He argues "exit standards" are the pressing issue—defining expected growth levels from schooling. Don defines standards as three-component constructs: criteria (dimensions like vocabulary, style, grammar), rating scales (6-level example for writing from disorganized to creatively written), and benchmarks (industry-recognized reference points like a competent plumber who solves problems independently). He notes doctors use test results without averaging to determine patient health, while teachers average diverse subjects' grades—an illogical analogy. Don argues judgment cannot be removed from standards-setting, only made consistent, as doctors exemplify through using test results to inform judgment about treatment.

title: 500 Teachers as Change Agents
summary: Don defines teachers as change agents helping learners acquire behaviors for adult community participation, arguing content is the easy part. Learning, he states, is change—in cognitive, affective, or psychomotor domains. Learning is fundamentally individual; teachers don't teach classes but may teach multiple individuals within group settings. Teaching involves stimulating learning through diverse techniques: modeling, information delivery, questioning, timelines, projects, field trips, and assessment. The crux of good teaching is creating individual learning environments that yield favorable experiences. Don notes subjects serve as media for teaching broader skills—English teaches communication, school environment teaches citizenship. Good assessment focuses on what people actually do in real life: communicate, solve problems, discuss literature, analyze situations, not on memorizing isolated content.
content_preview:
Teachers as Change Agents







Teachers are change agents.  They help learners gain a set of behaviours needed to participate in adult community.  Content is the easy part.




To learn is to change; to teach is to help others change.  In educational jargon, changes may be in the cognitive, affective or psychomotor domains.  More simply put, a person who has learned has new or changed attitudes, skills or information or some combination thereof.  




Learning is an individual matter.  Only the learner can learn.    The stimulus for learning may be internal or external and the actual learning may take place in a group setting or when the individual is alone.  A teacher does not teach a class but a teacher may teach individuals at the same time in a group setting.  




The role of a teacher is to stimulate learning – to create a set of circumstances so that a learner learns the desired behaviour. To help a learner to learn is to help bring about changes in the learner.  Teachers need a variety of techniques in their tool kit – and they will likely require all of them.  Tools include setting an example, providing information, asking questions, setting time lines, assigning projects or home work, organizing field trips and assessing performance.  The trick for each teacher is to create a learning environment for each learner that will result in each learner having a favorable experience, even in a group setting.  Not easy but it is the crux of good teaching.




Teachers use subjects as a medium for teaching; most any subject serves as a medium through which to teach communication skills; perhaps the school environment is the best medium for teaching citizenship.  Most subjects can be used as a medium for teaching a number of skills.  Teachers use a variety of methods to both motivate and teach students assigned to their care such as having students take tests and exams, prepares course papers, participates in discussions and group activities, field trips.

title: 8 Graduation
summary: Open Education No. 63 (April 18, 2018), authored by Don Glendenning questioning whether current school calendars can coexist with learning excellence. He notes individual learner pace and style differences conflict with group-based instruction organized in time blocks, complicating diploma awards and graduation ceremonies. Don proposes five alternatives: schools focus on learning, not grading; independent bodies award grades; learning time adjusts to individual pace; graduation requirements change; Canadian Qualification Authority established; graduation becomes "recognition." The article references an education award program and discusses information as an education service separate from instruction. Don's personal reflection on an eye doctor's "Cataract Information for Patients" pamphlet raises whether comparable patient/learner information services exist, and a concluding poem lament reflects on teaching effectiveness when students face social challenges.

title: 94 Learning
summary: Don presents his philosophy of learning as personal, multi-faceted change in how people think, feel, and act. He stresses that learners carry three types of baggage into learning situations: innate conditions, prior learning, and aspirations about the future. Criticizing PEI's narrow focus on school-based education, he argues institutions must redesign programs to accommodate diverse learner needs and that educators must engage as professionals with communities they serve, not remain confined by political filters and bureaucratic constraints. His vision emphasizes that meaningful education develops lifelong competencies beyond credentialing.

IT’S ABOUT LEARNING

Learning is about people making change in their lives; more precisely it’s about changes in the way they  think, feel and act. Learning is a very personal matter; only learners can learn – in other words one person cannot learn for another person.  Learning itself is neutral, neither  good nor bad.  It’s value depends on the purpose for which learning is used.  While groups do not learn,  learning can take place in a group setting – in fact, some learning experiences require the participation of others. Certain physical, mental and emotional conditions with which they were born:
  
Prior learning resulting from formal study, home circumstances, travel, state of health, personal interests, culture and learning styles.

Larry Brideau and John Paul were drowned at Victoria Bridge, Black River, on June 10, 1938. (Or was it 1937?) And a year has passed away,

Since a boy cried: Come my comrades

Nobly does he try to save;

On that great and golden shore.

Don proposes specific poll questions: whether respondents favor greater school autonomy in daily operations and whether schools should post PISA results publicly. This represents Don's evidence-based approach to educational policy, grounded in international comparative research.

It is amazing how quickly nursery rhymes drop from view.  I was at a family gathering recently and none of the younger generation had ever heard this rhyme.
